Question: What is Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA)?
Answer: Red Hat Openshift Service on AWS (ROSA) is a fully-managed turnkey application platform that allows you to focus on what matters most, delivering value to your customers by building and deploying applications. Red Hat SRE experts manage the underlying platform so you don’t have to worry about the complexity of infrastructure management.
generated_answers:
Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) is a fully-managed turnkey application platform that provides a comprehensive set of features and capabilities for deploying and managing containerized applications. ROSA is built on top of Kubernetes and provides additional features and capabilities that are not available in Kubernetes, such as automated cluster operations, over-the-air platform upgrades, container management, automation (Operators), networking, load balancing, service mesh, CI/CD, firewall, monitoring, registry, authentication, and authorization capabilities. For more information, please refer to the following links: 
- [ROSA Webpage](https://www.openshift.com/products/amazon-openshift)
- [ROSA Workshop](https://www.rosaworkshop.io)
- [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html)

Question: What are the benefits of Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (Key Features)?
Answer:
- **Native AWS service:** Access and use Red Hat OpenShift on demand with a self-service on-boarding experience through the AWS management console.
- **Flexible, consumption-based pricing:** Scale as per your business needs and pay as you go with flexible pricing with an on-demand hourly or annual billing model.
- **Single bill for Red Hat OpenShift & AWS usage:**  Customers will receive a single bill from AWS for both Red Hat OpenShift and AWS consumption.
- **Fully integrated support experience:** Installation, management, maintenance, and upgrades are performed by Red Hat site reliability engineers (SRE) with joint Red Hat and Amazon support and a 99.95% SLA.
- **AWS service integration:** AWS has a robust portfolio of cloud services, such as compute, storage, networking, database, analytics, and machine learning, which are directly accessible via Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS. This makes it easier to build, operate, and scale globally on demand through a familiar management interface.
Additional key features of Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS:
- **Maximum Availability:** Deploy clusters across multiple Availability Zones in supported Regions to maximize availability to maintain high availability for your most demanding mission-critical applications and data.
- **Cluster node scaling:** Easily add or remove compute nodes to match resource demand
- **Optimized clusters:** Choose from memory-optimized, compute-optimized, or general purpose EC2 instance types, with clusters sized to meet your needs. See [AWS compute types](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-aws-compute-types_rosa-service-definition).
- **Global availability:** Please refer to the [product regional availability page](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-regions-az_rosa-service-definition) page for an up-to-date view of where Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS is available.
generated_answers: You can find answers to frequently asked questions about Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) at the following link: https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/faq/index.html. This page provides information on topics such as pricing, support, and more.

Question: What are the differences between Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS and Kubernetes?
Answer: Everything you need to deploy and manage containers is bundled with ROSA, including container management, automation (Operators), networking, load balancing, service mesh, CI/CD, firewall, monitoring, registry, authentication, and authorization capabilities. These components are tested together for unified operations as a complete platform. Automated cluster operations, including over-the-air platform upgrades, further enhance your Kubernetes experience.
generated_answers: You can find answers to frequently asked questions about Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) at the following link: https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/faq/index.html. This page provides answers to questions about ROSA's features, pricing, and support.

Question: What exactly am I responsible for and what is Red Hat / AWS responsible for?
Answer: In short, anything that is related to deploying the cluster or keeping the cluster running will be Red Hat’s or AWS’s responsibility, and anything relating to the applications, users, or data is the customers responsibility.  Please see our [responsibility matrix](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-policy-responsibility-matrix.html) for more details.
generated_answers:
Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) is a fully-managed turnkey application platform that allows you to focus on what matters most, delivering value to your customers by building and deploying applications. Red Hat SRE experts manage the underlying platform so you don’t have to worry about the complexity of infrastructure management. 

When you provision ROSA clusters, you will incur the infrastructure and OpenShift charges at the pay-as-you-go hourly rate. Red Hat and AWS are responsible for the monitoring and maintenance of the ROSA cluster, while the customer is responsible for the applications, workloads, and data that they deploy to the cluster. For more information, please refer to our [responsibility matrix](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-policy-responsibility-matrix.html) and [pricing page](https://www.openshift.com/products/amazon-openshift/pricing).

Question: How does it work?
Answer: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) has infrastructure components (virtual machines, storage disks, etc.) and a software component (OpenShift). When you provision ROSA clusters you will incur the infrastructure and OpenShift charges at the pay-as-you-go hourly rate. Refer to the Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS pricing page for more information. You can also do 1 or 3 year commits for even deeper discounts.
generated_answers:
Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) is a fully-managed turnkey application platform that allows you to focus on what matters most, delivering value to your customers by building and deploying applications. Red Hat SRE experts manage the underlying platform so you don’t have to worry about the complexity of infrastructure management.

ROSA provides a secure, scalable, and reliable platform for running applications on AWS. It is designed to make it easy to deploy and manage applications on AWS, with features such as automated scaling, automated patching, and integrated logging and monitoring. ROSA also provides a unified experience for developers, allowing them to use the same tools and processes to develop and deploy applications on AWS as they would on-premises.

You can find more information at the following links:

To enable an AWS Support plan, see [How do I sign up for an AWS Support plan?](http://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/sign-up-support/). Question: How is the pricing of Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS calculated?
Answer:
See here for pricing information: [ROSA Pricing](https://aws.amazon.com/rosa/pricing/) Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS has three components to its cost. - First there is an hourly cluster fee, which is $0.03/cluster/hour (or approximately $263/cluster/year.) - The second component is the pricing per worker node, which is: - $0.171 per 4vCPU/hour for on-demand consumption (or approximately $1498/node/year.) - $0.114 per 4vCPU/hour for a 1-year RI commitment (or approximately $998/node/year.) - $0.076 per 4vCPU/hour for a 3-year RI commitment (or approximately $665/node/year.) - Third, are the underlying AWS infrastructure costs, like EC2 instances, network traffic, S3 buckets, etc. See here for [provisioned resources](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_planning/rosa-sts-aws-prereqs.html#rosa-aws-policy-provisioned_rosa-sts-aws-prereqs). _*OpenShift pricing for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS is the same for all supported AWS regions. Pricing listed above does not include infrastructure expenses._ **ON-DEMAND PRICING EXAMPLE** If you have a 10 worker node cluster of type m5.xlarge, running on-demand for a year, the OpenShift cost for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS would be approximately: $0.03 /cluster/hour X 1 cluster X 24 hours/day X 365.25 days/year = $263
$0.171 /node/hour X 10 worker nodes X 24 hours/day X 365 days/year = $14,969.60
Your total cost in this case would be $15,242
_Pricing for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS is in addition to the costs of Amazon EC2 for control plane, infra & worker nodes and other AWS services used._

Question: When pricing out my EC2 instances, do I need to use RHEL for the operating system?
Answer:
No, being that ROSA includes Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS) as the operating system, you only need to choose Linux.
For clarity, ROSA cluster creation handles the setup of all the RHCOS nodes entirely.
generated_answers: Yes, additional MachinePools can be configured with Spot instances. Using Amazon EC2 Spot instances allows you to take advantage of unused capacity at a significant cost savings. Question: Does Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS qualify for the AWS EDP Program?
Answer: Yes, Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS fully qualifies for 100% of the spend on the AWS Enterprise Discount Program.
generated_answers:
Yes, Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS qualifies for the AWS EDP Program. The program requires customers to meet certain AWS service quotas in order to run an Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS cluster. These quotas include:
- EC2 instances
- EBS volumes
- VPCs
- Security Groups
- Subnets
- IAM roles
- Route tables
- Network ACLs
- Elastic Load Balancing
- Amazon CloudWatch
- Amazon CloudFormation
- Amazon S3
- Amazon RDS
- Amazon ElastiCache
- Amazon DynamoDB
- Amazon SNS
- Amazon SQS
- Amazon ECS
- Amazon ECR
- Amazon EKS

For more information, please refer to the [AWS EDP Program Documentation](https://aws.amazon.com/partners/enterprise-discount-program/).

Question: Can I use spot/preemptible VMs?
Answer: Yes, additional MachinePools can be configured with Spot instances. Using Amazon EC2 Spot instances allows you to take advantage of unused capacity at a significant cost savings. Please see the [Creating a machine pool](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_cluster_admin/rosa_nodes/rosa-managing-worker-nodes.html#creating_machine_pools_cli_rosa-managing-worker-nodes) section in the documentation for more information.
generated_answers:
Yes, you can use spot/preemptible VMs with Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA). You can configure your machine pool to deploy machines as non-guaranteed AWS Spot Instances. To do this, select "Use Amazon EC2 Spot Instances" when creating the machine pool. You can leave "Use On-Demand instance price" selected to use the on-demand instance price, or select "Set maximum price" to define a maximum hourly price for a Spot Instance. 

Note that your Amazon EC2 Spot Instances might be interrupted at any time, so use Amazon EC2 Spot Instances only for workloads that can tolerate interruptions. Additionally, if you select "Use Amazon EC2 Spot Instances" for a machine pool, you cannot disable the option after the machine pool is created. 

For more information about Amazon EC2 Spot Instances, see the AWS documentation: https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/spot/.

Question: Is there an upfront commitment?
Answer: There is no required upfront commitment. ROSA clusters can be provisioned on-demand, with pay-as-you-go billing, for both AWS & OpenShift expenses. In this case, there is no upfront commitment. One year & three year RI pricing is also available to take advantage of pricing discounts.
generated_answers: No, you do not need to sign/have a contract with Red Hat to use ROSA. You will need a Red Hat account for use on console.redhat.com which includes accepting our Enterprise Agreement and Online services terms. You can acquire the service directly from the AWS console. As with other AWS services, such as EC2, just spin up your OpenShift clusters and you will be charged based on your consumption. You can also contact your Red Hat or AWS representative. Here is a [short video](https://www.youtube.com/embed/KbzUbXWs6Ck) that demonstrates the process to deploy a ROSA cluster.

Question: How can I start using Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS?
Answer: You can acquire the service directly from the AWS console. As with other AWS services, such as EC2, just spin up your OpenShift clusters and you will be charged based on your consumption. You can also contact your Red Hat or AWS representative. Here is a [short video](https://www.youtube.com/embed/KbzUbXWs6Ck) that demonstrates the process to deploy a ROSA cluster.

Question: Is there a discount if I have unused OCP subscriptions?
Answer: Yes! Customers migrating non-ROSA OpenShift workloads to ROSA are eligible for a 75% discount off the ROSA service fee 1-year contract rate over the remaining term of their non-ROSA OpenShift subscriptions. IBM Cloud Pak customers migrating their Cloud Pak workloads to ROSA are eligible for a 50% discount off the ROSA service fee 1-year contract rate over the remaining term of their Cloud Pak licenses. These discounts can be obtained by contacting [aws-redhat-partnerteam@amazon.com](mailto:aws-redhat-partnerteam@amazon.com). The discounts apply only to ROSA service fees associated with the worker nodes running the migrated workloads. See also the [AWS ROSA pricing page](https://aws.amazon.com/rosa/pricing/).
generated_answers: ROSA is a fully-managed service, so you don't need to worry about the complexity of infrastructure management. Red Hat SRE experts are available to provide support and help with any issues you may have. Pricing for help is based on the type of support you need and the number of nodes in your cluster. You can find more information on pricing for help at the following link: [ROSA Pricing](https://aws.amazon.com/rosa/pricing/).

Question: Can I bring my own subscription to the service (e.g. Red Hat Cloud Access, OCP, IBM CloudPak)?
Answer: Existing non-ROSA OpenShift subscriptions cannot be directly used for ROSA, as billing occurs directly through AWS, preventing OpenShift Container Platform or OpenShift Dedicated subscriptions from being used with ROSA. Though, as stated in the previous question, customers can get a discount for unused subscriptions for the remaining term of their subscription, including IBM CloudPaks.

Question: Can I purchase middleware subscriptions on-demand for my ROSA clusters?
Answer: Middleware subscriptions (e.g, Integration or Runtimes) are purchased from Red Hat yearly via the standard process.  Currently, there is no on-demand purchasing ability for your ROSA clusters.

Question: Which compliance certifications does ROSA have so far?
Answer: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS is currently compliant with SOC-1, SOC-2 type 1 & type 2, ISO-27001, & PCI-DSS. We are also currently working towards FedRAMP High, HIPAA, ISO 27017 and ISO 27018 as well.
generated_answers: No, all nodes in a Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS cluster must be located in the same AWS region; this follows the same model as that of OCP. For clusters configured for multiple availability zones control plane nodes and worker nodes will be distributed across the availability zones. For more information, please refer to the [Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html).

Question: Can a cluster have worker nodes across multiple AWS regions?
Answer: No, all nodes in a Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS cluster must be located in the same AWS region; this follows the same model as that of OCP. For clusters configured for multiple availability zones control plane nodes and worker nodes will be distributed across the availability zones.
generated_answers: No, a cluster cannot have worker nodes across multiple AWS regions. Each new Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS cluster is installed within an installer-created or preexisting Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) in a single region, with the option to deploy into a single availability zone (Single-AZ) or across multiple availability zones (Multi-AZ). This provides cluster-level network and resource isolation, and enables cloud-provider VPC settings, such as VPN connections and VPC Peering. For more information, see the [Regions and Availability Zones](https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/global-infrastructure/regions_az/) section in the AWS documentation.

Question: What is the minimum number of worker nodes that a ROSA cluster can have?
Answer: For a ROSA cluster the minimum is 2 worker nodes for single AZ and 3 for multiple AZ.

Question: Can an admin manage users and quotas?
Answer: Yes, a Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS customer administrator can manage users and quotas in addition to accessing all user created projects. Please see for example [resource quotas per project](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.10/applications/quotas/quotas-setting-per-project.html).

Administrators can grant users admin rights to help manage the cluster, as well as set quotas for resources such as CPU, memory, and storage. For more information on managing users and profiles, please refer to the ROSA Documentation [here](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/4.5/admin_guide/managing_users_and_profiles.html).

Question: When will features of the latest version of Kubernetes be supported in ROSA via OpenShift 4?
Answer: Customers are able to upgrade to the newest version of OpenShift in order to inherit the features from that version of OpenShift (see [life cycle dates](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-life-cycle.html#rosa-life-cycle-dates_rosa-life-cycle)). Note, that since ROSA is an opinionated installation of OpenShift Container Platform, not all features may be available on ROSA. Please review the [Service Definition](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-service-definition.html).

Question: How can customers get support for the service?
Answer:
ROSA is supported by AWS and Red Hat, and you have the option to contact support from either company to begin troubleshooting. Any escalations that are necessary will be facilitated as necessary by AWS and Red Hat to engage the best team to address the issues.
  - [Red Hat Support](https://access.redhat.com/)
  - [AWS Support](https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/) (Customer must have valid AWS support contract)
You can also visit the [Red Hat Customer Portal](http://access.redhat.com/) to search or browse through the Red Hat Knowledgebase of articles and solutions relating to Red Hat products or to submit a support case to Red Hat Support. Or you can open up a ticket directly from [OpenShift Cluster Manager](https://console.redhat.com/openshift) (OCM).  See the [ROSA documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_support/rosa-getting-support.html) for more details about obtaining support.

Customers can also use the OpenShift Cluster Manager (OCM) to open a ticket directly. For more information, please refer to the ROSA documentation at https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_support/rosa-getting-support.html.

Question: What happens if I do not upgrade my cluster before the "end of life" date?
Answer: Nothing will happen to an existing ROSA cluster. Your ROSA cluster will continue to operate though it will be in a "limited support" status. In short, this means that the SLA for that cluster will no longer be applicable, but you can still get support for that cluster.  Please see [Limited support status](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-life-cycle.html#rosa-limited-support_rosa-life-cycle) for more details.

Question: What version of OpenShift is running?
Answer: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS is a managed service which is based on OpenShift Container Platform. You can view the current version and [life cycle dates](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-life-cycle.html#rosa-life-cycle-dates_rosa-life-cycle) in the ROSA documentation.
generated_answers: The underlying node OS used for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS is Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS). RHCOS is a minimal operating system designed to run containerized workloads securely and at scale. It is optimized for running containerized applications and provides a secure, reliable, and consistent environment for running them. For more information, please refer to the [RHCOS Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.5/nodes/nodes/understanding-nodes.html#understanding-nodes_understanding-nodes).

Question: Is Open Service Broker for AWS (OBSA) supported?
Answer: Yes, you can use OSBA with Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS.  See [Open Service Broker for AWS](https://aws.amazon.com/partners/servicebroker/) for more information. Though a more recent development is the [AWS Controller for Kubernetes](https://github.com/aws-controllers-k8s/community). This is the preferred method.
generated_answers: The underlying node OS used for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) is Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS). RHCOS is a minimal operating system designed to run containerized workloads securely and at scale. For more information, please refer to the [RHCOS documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.5/nodes/nodes/nodes-rhel-coreos.html).

Question: What is the underlying node OS used?
Answer: As with all OpenShift v4.x offerings, the control plane, infra and worker nodes run Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS).
generated_answers: The underlying node OS used in Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) is Red Hat Enterprise Linux CoreOS (RHCOS). RHCOS is a minimal operating system designed to run containerized workloads securely and at scale. It is optimized for running containerized applications and provides a secure, reliable, and consistent environment for running applications. For more information, please refer to the [RHCOS Documentation](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux_coreos/).

Question: What is the process for customers wishing to ‘offboard’ their deployment in ROSA - is there a process?
Answer: Customers can stop using the service anytime and move their applications to on-prem, private cloud or other cloud providers.  Standard reserved instances (RI) policy applies for unused RI.
generated_answers: Yes, ROSA provides a command line interface (CLI) for deploying clusters. You can find more information about the ROSA CLI and how to use it to deploy a cluster at the following link: https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/16-deploy_cli.html.

Question: What authentication mechanisms are supported with ROSA?
Answer: OpenID Connect (a profile of OAuth2), Google OAuth, GitHub OAuth, GitLab, and LDAP.
generated_answers: The recommended authentication mechanism for ROSA is AWS STS. This method better aligns with principles of least privilege and is much better aligned to secure practices in cloud service resource management. For more information, please see the section "[ROSA with STS Explained](15-sts_explained.md)" for a detailed explanation.

Question: How will events such as product updates and scheduled maintenance be communicated?
Answer: Red Hat will provide updates via email and Red Hat console service log.
generated_answers: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) customers will be notified of new features and updates through the regular communication channels, including AWS updates and email. Additionally, customers can add notification contacts for their ROSA cluster and subscribed users will receive emails about cluster events that require customer action, known cluster incidents, upgrade maintenance, and other topics. For more information, please refer to the [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html).

Question: Does ROSA have a hibernation or shut-down feature for any nodes in the cluster to save costs on infrastructure or to retain a configured cluster for long-term?
Answer: No, not at this time. The shutdown/hibernation feature is an OpenShift platform feature not yet mature enough for widespread cloud services use.
generated_answers: Yes, ROSA supports node autoscaling. Autoscaling allows you to automatically adjust the size of the cluster based on the current workload. You can find more information about autoscaling nodes on a cluster in the ROSA documentation at the following link: https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_cluster_admin/rosa_nodes/rosa-nodes-about-autoscaling-nodes.html.

Question: Is SRE access to clusters secured by MFA?
Answer: Yes, all SRE access is secured by MFA. See [SRE access](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-policy-process-security.html#rosa-policy-sre-access_rosa-policy-process-security) in the documentation for more details.
generated_answers: If you specify a KMS key to use, the following will be encrypted with that key: control plane, infrastructure and worker node root volumes, along with your persistent volumes. For more information, please refer to the [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html).

Question: What encryption keys, if any, are used in a new ROSA cluster?
Answer: We encrypt EBS volumes that we use for ROSA, using a key stored in KMS. Customers have the option to provide their own KMS keys at cluster creation time as well.
generated_answers: Yes, ROSA supports the use of customer-supplied KMS keys for EBS encryption. To configure a cluster with a custom KMS Key, you can refer to the ROSA STS Customizations documentation [here](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_install_access_delete_clusters/rosa-sts-creating-a-cluster-with-customizations.html#rosa-sts-creating-cluster-customizations_rosa-sts-creating-a-cluster-with-customizations) and the Deploy ROSA with a Custom KMS Key guide [here](https://mobb.ninja/docs/rosa/kms/). Using a customer-managed KMS key allows you to have full control over the KMS key including key policies, key rotation and deletion.

Question: If I specify a KMS key to use, what exactly gets encrypted with that key?
Answer: Control plane, infrastructure and worker node root volumes, along with your persistent volumes.
generated_answers:
If you specify a KMS key to use, the following will be encrypted with that key: control plane, infrastructure and worker node root volumes, along with your persistent volumes. You should see the StorageClass set to `gp3-customer-kms`. This is the default StorageClass which is encrypted using the customer-provided key. For more information, please refer to the following links: 

- [ROSA STS Customizations](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_install_access_delete_clusters/rosa-sts-creating-a-cluster-with-customizations.html#rosa-sts-creating-cluster-customizations_rosa-sts-creating-a-cluster-with-customizations)
- [Deploy ROSA with a Custom KMS Key](https://mobb.ninja/docs/rosa/kms/)

Question: Is data on my cluster encrypted?
Answer:
By default, there is encryption at rest. The AWS Storage platform automatically encrypts your data before persisting it, and decrypts the data before retrieval. See [AWS EBS Encryption](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSEncryption.html) details.
There is also the ability to encrypt etcd in the cluster, and that would combine with AWS storage encryption, resulting in double the encryption (redundant), which adds up to 20% performance hit. For further details see [etcd encryption](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_policy/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-etcd-encryption_rosa-service-definition).
generated_answers: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) provides encryption for data stored on the cluster. Data is encrypted at rest using AES-256 encryption. Additionally, data is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2. For more information, please refer to the [ROSA Security Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/4.5/security/index.html).

Question: When can etcd encryption be done with a ROSA cluster?
Answer:
Only at cluster creation time, can etcd encryption be enabled.
Note that this incurs additional overhead with negligible security risk mitigation.
See the prior question about EBS encryption.
generated_answers:
When creating a ROSA cluster, the following infrastructure is provisioned:
- Virtual Machines
- Storage
- Load Balancers
- Networking
- Security Groups
- IAM Roles
- OpenID Connect (OIDC) Provider

For more information, please refer to the ROSA documentation on [AWS prerequisites](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_planning/rosa-sts-aws-prereqs.html#rosa-aws-policy-provisioned_rosa-sts-aws-prereqs).

Question: How is etcd encryption configured in a ROSA cluster?
Answer: The same as in OCP. The aescbc cypher is used and the setting is patched during cluster deployment. [Relevant Kubernetes documentation](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/encrypt-data/). For further details see [etcd encryption](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_policy/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-etcd-encryption_rosa-service-definition).
generated_answers:
Etcd encryption can be enabled at cluster creation time in Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA). This encryption will encrypt the key values in etcd, but not the keys. The resources that will be encrypted include secrets, config maps, routes, OAuth access tokens, and OAuth authorize tokens. Enabling etcd encryption will incur a performance overhead of approximately 20%. For more information, please refer to the following links: 

- [Understanding process and security for ROSA](#rosa-policy-process-security)
- [ROSA life cycle](#rosa-life-cycle)
- [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html)
- [Kubernetes Documentation](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/encrypt-data/)
- [AWS EBS Encryption](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSEncryption.html)
- [etcd encryption](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_policy/rosa-service-

Question: What infrastructure is provisioned as part of a new ROSA cluster?
Answer: ROSA makes use of a number of different cloud services such as virtual machines, storage, load balancers, etc. You can see a defined list in the [AWS prerequisites](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_planning/rosa-sts-aws-prereqs.html#rosa-aws-policy-provisioned_rosa-sts-aws-prereqs).
generated_answers: ROSA provides a secure network configuration using firewall rules for AWS Security Groups and DDoS protection with AWS Shield Standard. Customers can optionally configure their ROSA cluster endpoints to be made private so that the cluster control plane and applications are not accessible from the Internet. AWS customers can configure a private network connection to their ROSA cluster through technologies such as AWS VPC peering, AWS VPN, or AWS Direct Connect. Additionally, customers can add notification contacts for a ROSA cluster. Subscribed users receive emails about cluster events that require customer action, known cluster incidents, upgrade maintenance, and other topics. For more information, please visit the ROSA Webpage at https://www.openshift.com/products/amazon-openshift.

Question: I see there are two "kinds" of ROSA clusters. One uses an IAM user with admin permissions and the other AWS STS. Which should I choose?
Answer: AWS STS. These aren't "kinds" but rather credential methods. Basically, "how do you grant Red Hat the permissions needed in order to perform the required actions in your AWS account?". The roadmap forward is focused on STS, and the IAM user method will eventually be deprecated. This better aligns with principles of least privilege and is much better aligned to secure practices in cloud service resource management. Please see the section [ROSA with STS Explained](/rosa/15-sts_explained) for a detailed explanation.
generated_answers: There are currently two supported credential methods when deploying a ROSA cluster. The first method uses an IAM user with the *AdministratorAccess* policy (limited to the AWS account using ROSA) that allows the installer to create all the resources it needs, and allows the cluster to create/expand its own credentials as needed. The second, more recent, and **recommended** method uses AWS STS. This method uses predefined roles and policies to grant the service minimal permissions needed (least-privilege) to the AWS account in order to create and operate the cluster. Please see the section "[ROSA with STS Explained](15-sts_explained.md)" for a detailed explanation.

Question: I’m seeing a number of permission or failure errors related to prerequisite tasks or cluster creation, what might be the problem?
Answer: Please check for a newer version of the ROSA CLI. Every release of the ROSA CLI lands in two places: [Github](https://github.com/openshift/rosa/releases) and the [Red Hat signed binary releases](https://www.openshift.com/products/rosa/download).
generated_answers: If you are seeing permission or failure errors related to prerequisite tasks or cluster creation, it is likely due to one of the prerequisites not being met. Ensure that you are logged in as an IAM user and not an assumed role or STS user, that you have administrator access to the AWS account of the cluster, and that you have access to the cluster as a user with the `cluster-admin` role. Additionally, if Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS created a VPC, you must remove any network configurations, such as VPN configurations and VPC peering connections, and any additional services that were added to the VPC before you can successfully delete your cluster. Finally, make sure that you have the Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS CLI (`oc`) installed. For more information, please refer to the ROSA Documentation at https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html.

Question: What are the available storage options?
Answer: Please refer to the [storage](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-storage_rosa-service-definition) section of the service definition.
generated_answers:
Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) provides two prebuilt storage classes that use AWS Elastic Block Store (EBS) volumes. These storage classes are ready to use and some familiarity with Kubernetes and AWS is assumed. The two storage classes are gp3 and gp3-csi, with gp3 set as the default.

In addition, you can configure storage for the Collector, Ingester, and Query services under `spec.storage`. Multiple instances of each of these components can be provisioned as required for performance and resilience purposes.

For more information, please refer to the following documentation:
- [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html)
- [Storage Classes](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/4.5/storage/storage_classes.html)
- [Distributed Tracing Storage Configuration Options](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/4.5/distributed_tracing/distributed_tracing_storage_configuration_options.html)

Question: What options are available to use shared storage in containers?
Answer: AWS EFS (Using AWS EFS CSI Driver, OpenShift includes the CSI driver out of the box in 4.10.). See [Setting up AWS EFS for Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/storage/persistent_storage/osd-persistent-storage-aws.html).
generated_answers:
For Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA), there are several options available for shared storage in containers. These include using persistent volumes, distributed tracing storage, and replicated databases. 

Persistent volumes are attached to single pods and can provide a way to store data that is accessible to multiple containers. This can be used to store data that needs to be shared between containers, such as application configuration or user data.

Distributed tracing storage is used to store data related to distributed tracing. This data is used to track the performance of applications and services. The storage configuration options for distributed tracing can be configured under the `spec.storage` section.

Replicated databases can also be used to provide shared storage for containers. This can be used to store data that needs to be shared between containers, such as application configuration or user data. Replicated databases can provide a more reliable and resilient way to store data than single persistent volumes. 

For more information, please refer to the ROSA Documentation at https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html.

Question: Can I deploy into an already existing VPC and choose the specific subnets?
Answer: Yes.  At install time you are able to select whether you’d like to deploy to an existing VPC and then choose that VPC.  You will then be able to select the desired subnets and also provide a valid CIDR range (encompassing the subnets) the installer will handle using those subnets. Please see the [VPC](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_planning/rosa-sts-aws-prereqs.html#rosa-vpc_rosa-sts-aws-prereqs) section in the documentation for further details.
generated_answers: Yes, you can deploy into an already existing VPC and choose the specific subnets. At install time you are able to select whether you’d like to deploy to an existing VPC and then choose that VPC. You will then be able to select the desired subnets and also provide a valid CIDR range (encompassing the subnets) the installer will handle using those subnets. Please see the [VPC](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_planning/rosa-sts-aws-prereqs.html#rosa-vpc_rosa-sts-aws-prereqs) section in the documentation for further details.

Question: Which network plugin is used in Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS?
Answer: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS uses the default OpenShift SDN network provider configured to NetworkPolicy mode. OVN-Kubernetes is on our roadmap.
generated_answers: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS uses the OpenShift SDN network provider configured to NetworkPolicy mode by default. OVN-Kubernetes is supported on Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS 4.7.32+, Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS 4.8.12+, and Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS 4.9+. Additionally, third-party Container Network Interface (CNI) plugins that have been certified on Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS and passed Service Mesh conformance testing can be used. For more information, please see the [Certified OpenShift CNI Plug-ins](https://access.redhat.com/articles/5436171) page.

Question: Is cross-namespace networking supported?
Answer: Cluster admins in ROSA can customize cross-namespace networking (including denying it) on a per project basis using NetworkPolicy objects. Refer to [Configuring multitenant isolation with network policy](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.10/networking/network_policy/multitenant-network-policy.html) on how to configure.
generated_answers:
Yes, cross-namespace networking is supported on Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS. You can configure non-default pod network permissions for project and pod networks, pod ingress, and pod egress using NetworkPolicy objects. You can also use OpenShift Cluster Manager to request a private load balancer for default application routes, configure up to one additional public or private router shard and corresponding load balancer, request and configure any additional service load balancers for specific services, and configure any necessary DNS forwarding rules. Additionally, you can enable multicast for a project and use third-party Container Network Interface (CNI) plugins that have been certified on Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS and passed Service Mesh conformance testing. For more information, please refer to the following links: 

- [Certified OpenShift CNI Plug-ins](https://access.redhat.com/articles/5436171)
- [OpenShift SDN Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.5/networking/openshift_sdn/index.html)
- [OVN-Kubernetes Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.5/

Question: Can more than one ROSA cluster be set up in one VPC?
Answer: Yes, ROSA allows multiple clusters to share the same VPC. Essentially, the number of clusters would be limited by what AWS resource quota remains, as well as any chosen CIDR ranges that must not overlap. See [CIDR Range Definitions](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/networking/cidr-range-definitions.html) for more information.
generated_answers: Yes, you can set up more than one ROSA cluster in one VPC. Each cluster will need its own CIDR range that does not overlap with other clusters in the same VPC. You can use AWS VPC peering, AWS VPN, or AWS Direct Connect to configure a private network connection to your ROSA cluster. Additionally, you can use OpenShift User Workload Monitoring to monitor containers and manage capacity using Prometheus/Grafana. For production workloads, it is recommended to deploy ROSA clusters across multiple availability zones for the highest level of fault tolerance.

Question: Can I use Prometheus/Grafana to monitor containers and manage capacity?
Answer: Yes, using OpenShift User Workload Monitoring. This is a check-box option in OpenShift Cluster Manager (console.redhat.com/openshift)
generated_answers:
Yes, you can use Prometheus/Grafana to monitor containers and manage capacity on Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA). Prometheus is used to collect metrics from the cluster components and Grafana is used to visualize the metrics. You can use the OpenShift monitoring dashboard to run Prometheus Query Language (PromQL) queries to examine metrics visualized on a plot. As a dedicated-admin, you can query one or more namespaces at a time for metrics about user-defined projects. As a developer, you must specify a project name when querying metrics and you must have the required privileges to view metrics for the selected project. For more information, please refer to the following links: 

- [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html)
- [OpenShift Monitoring Dashboard](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/4.5/monitoring/monitoring-dashboard.html)
- [Prometheus Query Language](https://prometheus.io/docs/prometheus/latest/querying/basics/)

Question: Can I see audit logs output from the cluster control-plane?
Answer: If the Cluster Logging Operator Add-on has been added to the cluster then audit logs are available through CloudWatch.  If it has not, then a support request would allow you to request some audit logs. Small targeted and time-boxed logs can be requested for export and sent to a customer. The selection of audit logs available are at the discretion of SRE in the category of platform security and compliance. Requests for exports of a cluster’s entirety of logs will be rejected.
generated_answers: Yes, ROSA worker nodes use a different AMI from OSD and OCP. The control plane and infra node AMIs are common across products in the same version. For more information, please refer to the [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html).

Question: Can I use an AWS Permissions Boundary around the policies for my cluster?
Answer: Yes, using AWS Permissions Boundary is supported.
generated_answers: Yes, you can use an AWS Permissions Boundary around the policies for your ROSA cluster. You will need to create a trust policy, create a role for AWS Prometheus and CloudWatch, create an IAM Role trust policy for the cluster, and attach the IAM Policy to the IAM Role. Please refer to the [documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa-sts-about-iam-resources.html) for more details.

Question: Do ROSA worker nodes share the same AMI as other OpenShift products?
Answer: ROSA worker nodes use a different AMI from OSD and OCP. Control Plane and Infra node AMIs are common across products in the same version.
generated_answers: No, all nodes in a Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS cluster must be located in the same AWS region. This follows the same model as that of OpenShift Container Platform (OCP). However, for clusters configured for multiple availability zones, control plane nodes and worker nodes will be distributed across the availability zones. For more information, please refer to the [OpenShift Container Platform documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.4/architecture/infrastructure_components/regions-and-zones.html).

Question: Are backups taken for clusters?
Answer: Only non-STS clusters have SRE managed backups at this time, which means that ROSA STS clusters don’t have backups. You can also see our [backup policy](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-backup-policy_rosa-service-definition). It is imperative for users to have their own backup policies for applications and data.
generated_answers: No, the ROSA CLI does not currently accept Multi-region KMS keys for EBS encryption. However, it does accept single region KMS keys for EBS Encryption as long as it is defined at cluster creation time. For more information, please refer to the [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html).

Question: Is ROSA GDPR Compliant?
Answer: Yes: [https://www.redhat.com/en/gdpr](https://www.redhat.com/en/gdpr)
generated_answers: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) is GDPR compliant and meets the requirements of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). ROSA provides a ROSA-required service quota to ensure that customers have the resources they need to meet their GDPR requirements. Additionally, customers can add notification contacts for their ROSA cluster to receive emails about cluster events that require customer action, known cluster incidents, upgrade maintenance, and other topics. ROSA also provides cluster-specific Operator roles to help customers manage their clusters and ensure GDPR compliance. For more information, please refer to the following link: https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/4.5/compliance/gdpr.html.

Question: Does the ROSA CLI accept Multi-region KMS keys for EBS encryption?
Answer: Not at this time. This feature is in our backlog. Though we do accept single region KMS keys for EBS Encryption as long as it is defined at cluster creation time.
generated_answers: Yes, the ROSA CLI does accept Multi-region KMS keys for EBS encryption. To configure a cluster with a custom KMS Key, you must create a symmetric KMS key and provide the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) when creating your cluster. To create a customer managed KMS key, follow the procedure for [Creating symmetric encryption KMS keys](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/create-keys.html#create-symmetric-cmk). Additionally, the EBS operator role is required in addition to the account roles to successfully create your cluster. You can find more information on creating a ROSA cluster in STS mode with a custom KMS key in the official documentation [here](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_getting_started/rosa-sts-creating-a-cluster-with-customizations.html#rosa-sts-creating-cluster-customizations_rosa-sts-creating-a-cluster-with-customizations).

Question: Can I define a custom domain and certificate for my applications?
Answer: Yes. See [Configuring custom domains for applications](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/applications/deployments/osd-config-custom-domains-applications.html) for more information.
generated_answers: You can use the Knative (`kn`) CLI to dynamically issue a Certificate to every new Route. This approach allows you to securely expose multiple applications without having to manually update the Certificate resource. See [Dynamic TLS Certificates for Knative Routes](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/applications/deployments/osd-config-dynamic-tls-certificates-knative-routes.html) for more information.

Question: How are the ROSA domain certificates managed?
Answer: Red Hat infrastructure (Hive) manages certificate rotation for default application ingress (apps.*.openshiftapps.com)
generated_answers: ROSA domain certificates are managed by the ROSA service. The ROSA service automatically provisions and renews certificates for the domains associated with the cluster. Additionally, you can add notification contacts for a ROSA cluster. Subscribed users receive emails about cluster events that require customer action, known cluster incidents, upgrade maintenance, and other topics. For more information, please refer to the ROSA Documentation page: https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html.

Question: What features are upcoming for ROSA?
Answer: The current ROSA roadmap can be seen at: [https://red.ht/rosa-roadmap](https://red.ht/rosa-roadmap)
generated_answers: You can manage alerts for your ROSA cluster by subscribing to notifications. Subscribed users receive emails about cluster events that require customer action, known cluster incidents, upgrade maintenance, and other topics. To learn more, please refer to the [ROSA Documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/welcome/index.html#managing-alerts_rosa-managing-alerts).

Question: What kind of instances are supported for worker nodes?
Answer: See [AWS compute types](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_architecture/rosa_policy_service_definition/rosa-service-definition.html#rosa-sdpolicy-aws-instance-types_rosa-service-definition) in the service definition for the up to date list of supported instance types.  Additionally, spot instances are supported.
generated_answers: Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS (ROSA) supports a variety of instance types for worker nodes. The default machine pool node type and size cannot be changed after the cluster is created. The supported instance types and sizes are: m5.metal (96† vCPU, 384 GiB), m5.xlarge (4 vCPU, 16 GiB), m5.2xlarge (8 vCPU, 32 GiB), m5.4xlarge (16 vCPU, 64 GiB), m5.8xlarge (32 vCPU, 128 GiB), m5.12xlarge (48 vCPU, 192 GiB), m5.16xlarge (64 vCPU, 256 GiB), m5.24xlarge (96 vCPU, 384 GiB), m5a.xlarge (4 vCPU, 16 GiB), m5a.2xlarge (8 vCPU, 32 GiB), m5a.4xlarge (16 vCPU, 64 GiB), m5a.8xlarge (32 vCPU, 128 GiB), m5a.12xlarge (48 vCPU, 192 GiB), m5a.16xlarge (64 vCPU,

Question: Does ROSA support an air-gapped, disconnected environment where the ROSA cluster does not have internet access?
Answer: No, the ROSA cluster must have egress to the internet to access our registry, S3, send metrics etc. The service requires a number of [egress endpoints](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_install_access_delete_clusters/rosa_getting_started_iam/rosa-aws-prereqs.html#osd-aws-privatelink-firewall-prerequisites). Ingress can be limited to PrivateLink (for Red Hat SRE) and VPN or similar for customer access.
generated_answers:
Yes, ROSA supports an air-gapped, disconnected environment where the ROSA cluster does not have internet access. In this case, ingress can be limited to PrivateLink (for Red Hat SRE) and VPN or similar for customer access. Additionally, node autoscaling is available, allowing you to automatically adjust the size of the cluster based on the current workload. For more information, please refer to the following resources: 
- [About autoscaling nodes on a cluster](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_cluster_admin/rosa_nodes/rosa-nodes-about-autoscaling-nodes.html)
- [Understanding the ROSA deployment workflow](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openshift_service_on_aws/4/html-single/installing_accessing_and_deleting_rosa_clusters/#rosa-understanding-the-deployment-workflow)

Question: Is node autoscaling available?
Answer: Yes. Autoscaling allows you to automatically adjust the size of the cluster based on the current workload. See [About autoscaling nodes on a cluster](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_cluster_admin/rosa_nodes/rosa-nodes-about-autoscaling-nodes.html) in the documentation for more details.
generated_answers: Yes, node autoscaling is available on Red Hat OpenShift Service on AWS. You can configure the autoscaler option to automatically scale the number of machines in a cluster. For more information, please refer to the following documentation link: [About autoscaling nodes on a cluster](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_cluster_admin/rosa_nodes/rosa-nodes-about-autoscaling-nodes.html).

Question: What is the maximum number of worker nodes that a cluster can support?
Answer: The maximum number of worker nodes is 180 per ROSA cluster.  See here for [limits and scalability](https://docs.openshift.com/rosa/rosa_planning/rosa-limits-scalability.html) considerations and more details on node counts.

Resource quotas can be set per project to limit the amount of resources that can be consumed by a project. For more information, please refer to the [Resource Quotas documentation](https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.10/applications/quotas/quotas-setting-per-project.html).
